# Cloudflare R2 Configuration
# Environment variables needed for manual R2 upload
# 
# For GitHub Actions: Set these as repository secrets
# For local testing: Export these in your shell or create a .env file
#
# DO NOT commit actual credentials to git!

# Your Cloudflare Account ID
# Find it in: Cloudflare Dashboard → R2
export R2_ACCOUNT_ID="your_account_id_here"

# Your R2 Bucket Name
export R2_BUCKET_NAME="marathon-calendar"

# R2 API Token Access Key ID
# Generate in: Cloudflare Dashboard → R2 → Manage R2 API Tokens
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID="your_access_key_id_here"

# R2 API Token Secret Access Key
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY="your_secret_access_key_here"

# Optional: Public URL for your R2 bucket
# This is either:
# 1. Your custom domain (e.g., https://calendar.yourdomain.com)
# 2. R2 public bucket URL (e.g., https://pub-xxxxx.r2.dev)
export R2_PUBLIC_URL="https://your-public-url-here"

# ============================================================
# Usage Instructions
# ============================================================
#
# For local testing:
# ------------------
# 1. Copy these variables to a new file (e.g., .env.local)
# 2. Fill in your actual values
# 3. Load in your shell:
#    source .env.local
# 4. Run the upload script:
#    ./scripts/upload_to_r2.sh
#
# For GitHub Actions:
# -------------------
# 1. Go to your repository on GitHub
# 2. Settings → Secrets and variables → Actions
# 3. Add each variable as a repository secret
# 4. The workflow will automatically use them
#
# Security Notes:
# ---------------
# - Never commit credentials to git
# - Add .env* to .gitignore
# - Rotate API tokens regularly
# - Use specific bucket permissions
# - Monitor R2 access logs
